questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department with profuse, watery diarrhea, severe dehydration, and vomiting for the past 24 hours. Physical examination reveals signs of dehydration, including dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. Stool examination confirms the presence of Vibrio cholerae. Which of the following cellular structures is disrupted by the cholera toxin to cause watery diarrhea?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Zonula occludens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholera toxin acts by increasing cAMP in intestinal cells, leading to chloride and water secretion. The zonula occludens (tight junctions) are disrupted, contributing to increased intestinal permeability and profuse, watery diarrhea. Preventing dehydration is crucial in the management of cholera.
  • ➤ Cholera toxin acts by increasing cAMP in intestinal cells, leading to chloride and water secretion.
  • ➤ Cholera toxin
  • ➤ cAMP
  • ➤ The zonula occludens (tight junctions) are disrupted, contributing to increased intestinal permeability and profuse, watery diarrhea.
  • ➤ zonula occludens
  • ➤ Preventing dehydration is crucial in the management of cholera.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is experiencing frequent multifocal seizures and has a characteristic <2.5 Hz spike-and-wave pattern on EEG. The neurologist decides to start an antiepileptic medication that can also be used for migraine prophylaxis and for managing alcohol cravings in adults. Which of the following drug is the neurologist thinking to start?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Topiramate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Topiramate is effective in treating Lennox-Gastaut syndrome and is also used for migraine prophylaxis and to reduce alcohol cravings . While valproate is also used in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome and migraine prevention, it is not typically used for managing alcohol cravings . Ethosuximide is primarily for absence seizures , and rufinamide is limited to seizures without additional benefits for migraines or alcohol use disorders.
  • ➤ Topiramate is effective in treating Lennox-Gastaut syndrome and is also used for migraine prophylaxis and to reduce alcohol cravings .
  • ➤ Topiramate
  • ➤ Lennox-Gastaut syndrome
  • ➤ migraine prophylaxis
  • ➤ alcohol cravings
  • ➤ While valproate is also used in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome and migraine prevention, it is not typically used for managing alcohol cravings .
  • ➤ valproate
  • ➤ alcohol cravings
  • ➤ Ethosuximide is primarily for absence seizures , and rufinamide is limited to seizures without additional benefits for migraines or alcohol use disorders.
  • ➤ Ethosuximide
  • ➤ absence seizures
  • ➤ rufinamide

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman at 33 weeks gestation presents for a routine ultrasound. The ultrasound shows fetal growth restriction, and Doppler studies are performed. Which of the following Doppler findings is not an indication for immediate delivery in a fetus with growth restriction?

options.label: A
options.text: Absent end diastolic flow in the umbilical artery

options.label: B
options.text: Reversal of a wave in the ductus venosus

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased pulsatility index (PI) of the uterine artery

questions.correct_answer: D. Decreased pulsatility index (PI) of the uterine artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Decreased pulsatility index (PI) of the uterine artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In fetal growth restriction (FGR), decreased pulsatility index (PI) of the uterine artery is not an indication for immediate delivery. Critical Doppler findings that do suggest the need for immediate delivery include absent end diastolic flow in the umbilical artery , reversal of a wave in the ductus venosus , and pulsatility of the umbilical vein , all of which indicate significant fetal compromise.
  • ➤ In fetal growth restriction (FGR), decreased pulsatility index (PI) of the uterine artery is not an indication for immediate delivery.
  • ➤ decreased pulsatility index (PI) of the uterine artery
  • ➤ Critical Doppler findings that do suggest the need for immediate delivery include absent end diastolic flow in the umbilical artery , reversal of a wave in the ductus venosus , and pulsatility of the umbilical vein , all of which indicate significant fetal compromise.
  • ➤ absent end diastolic flow in the umbilical artery
  • ➤ reversal of a wave in the ductus venosus
  • ➤ pulsatility of the umbilical vein

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is scheduled for elective surgery and requires a blood transfusion. To ensure the availability of compatible blood, the blood bank must store the donated blood units for several weeks before the procedure. The staff chooses a preservative solution that allows the blood to be stored for up to 35 days while maintaining cell viability. Which of the following preservatives is most appropriate for this purpose?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Citrate Phosphate Dextrose Adenine-1 (CPDA-1)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CPDA-1 allows blood storage for up to 35 days by maintaining red blood cell viability and ATP levels.
  • ➤ CPDA-1 allows blood storage for up to 35 days by maintaining red blood cell viability and ATP levels.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with one previous live birth presents to your clinic inquiring about the contraceptive implant, Implanon NXT, for long-term contraception. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to using this contraceptive method?

options.label: D
options.text: Recent cesarean delivery in a lactating woman

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Breast cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Breast cancer is an absolute contraindication to the use of hormonal contraceptives, including Implanon NXT, because of the potential for hormone-driven tumor growth. Progestin-only contraceptives are generally safe in patients without contraindications like breast cancer.
  • ➤ Breast cancer is an absolute contraindication to the use of hormonal contraceptives, including Implanon NXT, because of the potential for hormone-driven tumor growth.
  • ➤ Breast cancer
  • ➤ absolute contraindication
  • ➤ Progestin-only contraceptives are generally safe in patients without contraindications like breast cancer.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is prescribed a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) for chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The medication is provided as an enteric-coated tablet to ensure proper absorption. Which of the following is not an advantage of using enteric-coated tablets for drug delivery?

options.label: A
options.text: Protects the acid-labile drug from gastric acidity

options.label: B
options.text: Protects the gastric mucosa from irritant effects of certain drugs

options.label: C
options.text: Prolongs the half-life of the drug

options.label: D
options.text: Delivers drugs distal to the stomach

questions.correct_answer: C. Prolongs the half-life of the drug
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prolongs the half-life of the drug

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enteric coating is used to protect acid-labile drugs from gastric acidity , protect the stomach lining , and target drug delivery to the intestine . Enteric coating does not affect the drug’s half-life , which is influenced by metabolic and elimination pathways in the body.
  • ➤ Enteric coating is used to protect acid-labile drugs from gastric acidity , protect the stomach lining , and target drug delivery to the intestine .
  • ➤ Enteric coating
  • ➤ protect acid-labile drugs
  • ➤ gastric acidity
  • ➤ protect the stomach lining
  • ➤ target drug delivery
  • ➤ intestine
  • ➤ Enteric coating does not affect the drug’s half-life , which is influenced by metabolic and elimination pathways in the body.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) presents with new-onset headaches, blurred vision, and hypertension. Fundoscopic examination shows flame-shaped hemorrhages and cotton-wool spots consistent with hypertensive retinopathy. She has previously been treated with corticosteroids for lupus nephritis, but her renal function has worsened. A renal biopsy shows wire-loop lesions and extensive immune complex deposition in the glomeruli. Which of the following autoantibodies is most specific for this patient’s lupus-related renal pathology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anti-double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA) antibody

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anti-double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA) antibodies are highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and are strongly associated with lupus nephritis , making them a key marker for renal involvement in SLE.
  • ➤ Anti-double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA) antibodies are highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and are strongly associated with lupus nephritis , making them a key marker for renal involvement in SLE.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. An abdominal ultrasound reveals the presence of multiple gallstones with no evidence of wall thickening. The bile duct (BD) diameter is measured at 12 mm, and serum bilirubin levels are elevated at 2.8. The patient's alkaline phosphatase levels are significantly elevated at 380. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) MRCP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In summary, given the patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggesting the presence of common bile duct stones, an MRCP is the most appropriate initial step to visualize the biliary system and confirm the diagnosis.
  • ➤ In summary, given the patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggesting the presence of common bile duct stones, an MRCP is the most appropriate initial step to visualize the biliary system and confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 28 weeks gestation presents for a routine prenatal visit. On physical examination, the fundal height is measured at 24 cm. An ultrasound reveals oligohydramnios with absent amniotic fluid. The fetus is noted to have normal cardiac activity. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's oligohydramnios?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fetal posterior urethral valve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posterior urethral valves cause oligohydramnios due to obstruction of fetal urine outflow. Fetal urine production is essential for maintaining normal amniotic fluid levels, and obstruction leads to low or absent amniotic fluid, contributing to complications like pulmonary hypoplasia and other fetal abnormalities.
  • ➤ Posterior urethral valves cause oligohydramnios due to obstruction of fetal urine outflow.
  • ➤ Posterior urethral valves
  • ➤ oligohydramnios
  • ➤ Fetal urine production is essential for maintaining normal amniotic fluid levels, and obstruction leads to low or absent amniotic fluid, contributing to complications like pulmonary hypoplasia and other fetal abnormalities.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe headache, nausea, and visual disturbances. She has a known history of a pituitary adenoma. On examination, she has reduced visual acuity and bitemporal hemianopsia. A CT scan of the head reveals a hemorrhagic mass in the sella turcica. Her blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg, and laboratory tests reveal hyponatremia. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dexamethasone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In pituitary apoplexy , the immediate treatment with dexamethasone (or other steroids) is the priority to correct adrenal insufficiency, followed by further imaging and surgical intervention.
  • ➤ In pituitary apoplexy , the immediate treatment with dexamethasone (or other steroids) is the priority to correct adrenal insufficiency, followed by further imaging and surgical intervention.
  • ➤ pituitary apoplexy
  • ➤ dexamethasone

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of open-angle glaucoma visits her ophthalmologist for follow-up. She is being treated with various medications to lower her intraocular pressure (IOP). The physician wants to add a drug that specifically increases trabecular outflow to help manage her condition.   • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Netarsudil increases trabecular outflow by inhibiting Rho-kinase , making it effective in lowering intraocular pressure in glaucoma . Timolol and acetazolamide decrease aqueous humor production , while brimonidine affects uveoscleral outflow .

questions.text: A 55-year-old male is admitted to the ICU after a traumatic head injury. The clinician wants to assess the oculocephalic reflex, as part of the neurological evaluation. The test is performed by rapidly rotating the patient's head from side to side while observing eye movements. Which of the following cranial nerves are involved in the oculocephalic reflex? III IV VI VIII VII
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The oculocephalic reflex tests the integrity of cranial nerves III (Oculomotor) , VI (Abducens) , and VIII (Vestibulocochlear) . It is used to assess brainstem function, especially in unconscious patients. A positive reflex indicates that the brainstem pathways are intact and capable of coordinating eye movements in response to head movement.
  • ➤ The oculocephalic reflex tests the integrity of cranial nerves III (Oculomotor) , VI (Abducens) , and VIII (Vestibulocochlear) .
  • ➤ oculocephalic reflex
  • ➤ III (Oculomotor)
  • ➤ VI (Abducens)
  • ➤ VIII (Vestibulocochlear)
  • ➤ It is used to assess brainstem function, especially in unconscious patients.
  • ➤ A positive reflex indicates that the brainstem pathways are intact and capable of coordinating eye movements in response to head movement.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the clinic with her mother due to concerns about primary amenorrhea. On examination, she has normal secondary sexual characteristics, including breast development and normal pubic and axillary hair. Her LH and FSH levels are normal, and a pelvic ultrasound reveals an absent uterus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome is a congenital disorder characterized by the absence of the uterus and upper vaginal canal, leading to primary amenorrhea in women with normal secondary sexual development. These patients have normal ovarian function and normal hormone levels, with a 46,XX karyotype.
  • ➤ Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome is a congenital disorder characterized by the absence of the uterus and upper vaginal canal, leading to primary amenorrhea in women with normal secondary sexual development.
  • ➤ Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome
  • ➤ These patients have normal ovarian function and normal hormone levels, with a 46,XX karyotype.

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing maternal health outcomes in a developing country. To measure the risk of maternal death relative to the number of live births in the area, the researcher needs to calculate a key indicator. Which of the following best describes this indicator?

options.label: A
options.text: Calculating the ratio of maternal deaths to the number of married women alive during the study period.

options.label: B
options.text: Expressing maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, including deaths up to 14 days after pregnancy termination.

options.label: C
options.text: Dividing the annual number of maternal deaths by the total number of women aged 15-49 years during the study period.

options.label: D
options.text: Expressing maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, including deaths up to 42 days after pregnancy termination.

questions.correct_answer: D. Expressing maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, including deaths up to 42 days after pregnancy termination.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Expressing maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, including deaths up to 42 days after pregnancy termination.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) reflects the risk of maternal death in relation to live births, considering deaths occurring during pregnancy or within 42 days post-pregnancy. It is a critical measure of the quality of maternal healthcare and is used for tracking improvements in maternal health services.
  • ➤ The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) reflects the risk of maternal death in relation to live births, considering deaths occurring during pregnancy or within 42 days post-pregnancy.
  • ➤ It is a critical measure of the quality of maternal healthcare and is used for tracking improvements in maternal health services.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with recent weight gain and increased appetite is found to have elevated Agouti-related peptide (AgRP) levels in the hypothalamus. Which of the following best explains the physiological effect of increased AgRP activity?

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Agouti-related peptide (AgRP) inhibits melanocortin receptors in the hypothalamus, leading to increased appetite and reduced energy expenditure . This pathway is essential in the regulation of feeding behavior and energy balance .

questions.text: A 2-minute-old newborn has a heart rate of 50 beats/min despite receiving effective positive pressure ventilation (PPV) with a bag and mask. The healthcare team initiates chest compressions and continues ventilation, but the heart rate remains below 60 beats/min after 30 seconds of effective compressions and ventilation. What is the next best step in the management of this newborn?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase the rate of positive pressure ventilation

options.label: C
options.text: Reposition the head and continue ventilations

options.label: D
options.text: Administer a second dose of surfactant

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Administer intravenous epinephrine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In neonatal resuscitation, if a newborn's heart rate remains below 60 beats per minute despite 30 seconds of effective chest compressions and ventilation, epinephrine should be administered immediately.
  • ➤ In neonatal resuscitation, if a newborn's heart rate remains below 60 beats per minute despite 30 seconds of effective chest compressions and ventilation, epinephrine should be administered immediately.

questions.text: A term male infant is born via cesarean section to a 27-year-old G1P1 mother after an uncomplicated pregnancy. The baby develops tachypnea, grunting, and mild chest retractions within an hour of birth. Oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. A chest x-ray reveals hyperinflation with fluid in the interlobar fissures and no mediastinal shift. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: D. Transient tachypnea of the newborn
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Transient tachypnea of the newborn

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transient tachypnea of the newborn is characterized by delayed resorption of lung fluid, leading to respiratory distress soon after birth in term infants, especially following cesarean delivery without labor. The chest x-ray findings include hyperinflation and fluid in the interlobar fissures. Symptoms resolve with supportive care within 24 to 72 hours.
  • ➤ Transient tachypnea of the newborn is characterized by delayed resorption of lung fluid, leading to respiratory distress soon after birth in term infants, especially following cesarean delivery without labor.
  • ➤ The chest x-ray findings include hyperinflation and fluid in the interlobar fissures. Symptoms resolve with supportive care within 24 to 72 hours.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man is brought to the emergency department unconscious. He exhibits no spontaneous movement of his extremities and does not respond to voice or painful stimuli. questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with xanthomas on his palms and premature coronary artery disease. Laboratory tests reveal elevated total cholesterol and triglyceride levels. questions.text: A 30-year-old athlete sustains an injury to his Achilles tendon and requires surgical repair using a tendon graft.   • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The plantaris tendon is commonly used for tendon grafting in lower limb surgical procedures, such as Achilles tendon repair , due to its accessibility and minimal impact on function. questions.text: A forensic expert is investigating a case of suspected suffocation. The cause of death involves various types of mechanical asphyxia, but one listed method is not classified under suffocation. Which of the following is not typically considered a type of suffocation?

Throttling is a form of manual strangulation involving direct pressure on the neck, which makes it distinct from other types of suffocation, such as smothering, choking, and gagging. Recognizing these differences is essential in forensic medicine for accurately determining the mechanism of death in asphyxia cases.

questions.text: In cases of ethylene glycol poisoning and its characteristic metabolic acidosis, treatment involves correction of the acidosis, removal of any remaining ethylene glycol, and administration of an inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH), the enzyme that oxidizes ethylene glycol to the organic acids that cause the acidosis.   • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Competitive inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration, which increases the rate of the enzymatic reaction.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents to the emergency department with palpitations and dizziness. His ECG shows ventricular arrhythmia. The pathophysiology of ventricular action potentials is reviewed to understand the mechanism behind the abnormal electrical activity. Which of the following options correctly arranges the sequence of events in the ventricular action potential? A) Transient outward flow of potassium B) Repolarizing K⁺ currents C) Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels D) Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C, D, A, B

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The ventricular action potential consists of distinct phases that occur in the following sequence:
  • • C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels : This occurs during Phase 0 , where rapid sodium influx leads to depolarization of the ventricular membrane.
  • • C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels
  • • Phase 0
  • • D. Transient outward flow of potassium : During Phase 1 , a brief outward potassium current causes a small drop in membrane potential, initiating partial repolarization.
  • • D. Transient outward flow of potassium
  • • Phase 1
  • • A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels : In Phase 2 , calcium channels open, allowing calcium influx, which sustains the plateau phase , balancing the outward potassium flow.
  • • A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels
  • • Phase 2
  • • plateau phase
  • • B. Repolarizing K⁺ currents : During Phase 3 , calcium channels close, and potassium efflux dominates, causing repolarization of the membrane and the return to the resting membrane potential.
  • • B. Repolarizing K⁺ currents
  • • Phase 3
  • • This correct sequence is essential for coordinated contraction of the ventricular myocardium and proper cardiac function.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ventricular action potential occurs in a specific order: sodium channel opening (depolarization) , followed by transient potassium outflow , then calcium channel activation (plateau phase), and finally, potassium-driven repolarization . This sequence is critical for maintaining proper electrical and mechanical function of the heart.
  • ➤ The ventricular action potential occurs in a specific order: sodium channel opening (depolarization) , followed by transient potassium outflow , then calcium channel activation (plateau phase), and finally, potassium-driven repolarization .
  • ➤ ventricular action potential
  • ➤ sodium channel opening (depolarization)
  • ➤ transient potassium outflow
  • ➤ calcium channel activation
  • ➤ potassium-driven repolarization
  • ➤ This sequence is critical for maintaining proper electrical and mechanical function of the heart.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the clinic for her annual check-up. She has been using oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) for contraception for the past couple of years, without any significant side effects. She asks about long term risks associated with OCPs. Which of the following is considered the most serious complication of oral contraceptive usage?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Leg vein thrombosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Oral contraceptives increase the risk of thromboembolic events, including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism, which are among the most serious complications. Unilateral leg swelling and pain in a woman on OCPs should raise suspicion for DVT, and prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent life-threatening consequences. Milder side effects like headache, breakthrough bleeding, and breast tenderness are common but do not carry the same level of risk as thrombosis.
  • ➤ Oral contraceptives increase the risk of thromboembolic events, including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism, which are among the most serious complications.
  • ➤ Unilateral leg swelling and pain in a woman on OCPs should raise suspicion for DVT, and prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent life-threatening consequences.
  • ➤ Milder side effects like headache, breakthrough bleeding, and breast tenderness are common but do not carry the same level of risk as thrombosis.

questions.text: A public health researcher is compiling data on causes of death in India for a study on mortality trends. Which of the following sources are commonly used to gather causes of death data in India? Sample Registration System (SRS) Census Medical Certification of Cause of Death (MCCD) Verbal autopsy through Lay information
questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The sources are commonly used for collecting causes of death data in India:
  • • The sources are commonly used for collecting causes of death data in India:
  • • 1. Sample Registration System (SRS): This system provides continuous and reliable data on births, deaths, and causes of death through a dual recording system that includes a field investigator and local enumerators.
  • • 1.
  • • Sample Registration System
  • • 3. Medical Certification of Cause of Death (MCCD) : This method involves the certification of death causes by medical professionals for deaths that occur in hospitals or healthcare facilities.
  • • 3. Medical Certification of Cause of Death (MCCD)
  • • 4. Lay information and verbal autopsy : This method involves collecting information from family members or close contacts about the circumstances leading up to a person's death. It is particularly useful in rural and hard-to-reach areas where medical certification might not be available.
  • • 4. Lay information and verbal autopsy
  • • Other Option :
  • • Other Option
  • • 2. Census: Incorrect. Census does not collect specific causes of death data. The Census focuses on population counts and demographics rather than mortality causes.

questions.text: A study is conducted to assess the accuracy of rapid antigen testing in diagnosing influenza in a group of patients presenting with flu-like symptoms. A total of 180 patients were tested using the rapid antigen test, and their diagnosis was confirmed by a PCR test (gold standard). Out of 70 patients who tested positive on the rapid antigen test, 50 were confirmed to have influenza by PCR. Among the 110 patients who tested negative on the rapid test, 90 were confirmed to be free of influenza by PCR. Calculate the Positive Likelihood Ratio (LR+) and Negative Likelihood Ratio (LR−) for the rapid antigen test.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 3.57 and 0.4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Positive Likelihood Ratio (LR+) quantifies how much more likely a positive test result is in those with the disease compared to those without the disease. Negative Likelihood Ratio (LR−) indicates how much less likely a negative test result is in those with the disease compared to those without the disease. For the rapid antigen test in diagnosing influenza, an LR+ of 3.57 means that a positive test result is about 3.57 times more likely in a patient with the disease, and an LR− of 0.4 means that a negative result decreases the likelihood of the disease to 40% of the baseline probability.
  • ➤ Positive Likelihood Ratio (LR+) quantifies how much more likely a positive test result is in those with the disease compared to those without the disease.
  • ➤ Negative Likelihood Ratio (LR−) indicates how much less likely a negative test result is in those with the disease compared to those without the disease.
  • ➤ For the rapid antigen test in diagnosing influenza, an LR+ of 3.57 means that a positive test result is about 3.57 times more likely in a patient with the disease, and an LR− of 0.4 means that a negative result decreases the likelihood of the disease to 40% of the baseline probability.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with intermittent cyanosis and exercise intolerance that began 6 months ago and has progressively worsened. questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Eisenmenger syndrome

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the condition with the appropriate diagnostic test:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • A. Hirschsprung's disease : This is a congenital disorder in which nerve cells (ganglion cells) are absent from a segment of the bowel, usually the rectum or sigmoid colon, leading to a functional obstruction. Infants with Hirschsprung's typically have difficulty with bowel movements within the first days of life. The symptoms can include constipation, abdominal distension, and vomiting. It is diagnosed often in the neonatal period with a barium enema and confirmed with suction rectal biopsy showing the absence of ganglion cells.
  • • A. Hirschsprung's disease
  • • B. Posterior urethral valve (PUV) : PUV is a congenital malformation in male child where an abnormality of the posterior urethra prevents urine outflow. This can lead to urinary obstruction, distension of the bladder, and can subsequently cause damage to the kidneys. Common symptoms include weak urine stream, difficulty in urination, recurrent urinary tract infections, and failure to thrive. Diagnosis is usually made with a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).
  • • B.
  • • Posterior urethral valve (PUV)
  • • C. Choledochal cyst : This is a congenital dilation of the bile ducts, often causing obstruction. Patients may present with the classic triad of abdominal pain, jaundice, and an abdominal mass, although not all these signs may be evident. Over time, choledochal cysts can lead to complications like cholangitis, pancreatitis, or even malignancy. Diagnosis is typically done with imaging like ultrasound or MRCP, and definitive treatment is surgical removal.
  • • C.
  • • Choledochal cyst
  • • D. Intussusception : This is a medical condition in which a part of the intestine telescopes into another section, leading to bowel obstruction. It is the most common cause of bowel obstruction in children between the ages of 6 months and 3 years. Symptoms include sudden, severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and "currant jelly" stools (due to mucus and blood). The diagnosis can often be made with an ultrasound or CT abdomen showing the characteristic "target sign" and is typically treated with high pressure enema, although some cases may require surgical intervention.
  • • D.
  • • Intussusception

  • • Non-Rebreather Mask (NRBM) provides up to 80% FiO2 when properly fitted and the reservoir bag is kept inflated, ensuring a high concentration of oxygen is available for the patient.
  • • Non-Rebreather Mask (NRBM)
  • • Hudson Mask , also known as a simple mask, can deliver FiO2 levels between 40-60% based on the oxygen flow rate.
  • • Hudson Mask
  • • Nasal Cannula at 3 L/min Oxygen Flow typically provides 32% FiO2, making it suitable for patients requiring low to moderate additional oxygen.
  • • Nasal Cannula at 3 L/min Oxygen Flow

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oxygen delivery devices are an essential aspect of managing patients with respiratory distress or hypoxemia.

questions.text: Fibrous ankylosis is caused by which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) TB arthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ TB arthritis is the most directly associated with fibrous ankylosis due to the chronic inflammatory processes and tissue scarring it induces around the affected joint.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with a soft, painless swelling in the scrotal area that becomes more prominent during the day. On physical examination, the swelling is found to be transilluminant. Which of the following swellings is not expected to transilluminate brightly?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lymphadenopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Only fluid-filled swellings such as hydroceles, cysts, and meningoceles transilluminate brightly, while solid masses like lymphadenopathy do not. Understanding the differential diagnosis of transilluminating masses helps narrow down potential causes in clinical practice.
  • ➤ Only fluid-filled swellings such as hydroceles, cysts, and meningoceles transilluminate brightly, while solid masses like lymphadenopathy do not.
  • ➤ Understanding the differential diagnosis of transilluminating masses helps narrow down potential causes in clinical practice.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with progressive pain and stiffness in the joints of her hands. Physical examination reveals swelling and limited range of motion in the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally, with sparing of the distal interphalangeal joints. Ulnar deviation is noted. She reports that the stiffness is particularly severe in the morning but improves throughout the day. Which of the following HLA subtypes is most strongly associated with this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) HLA-DR4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rheumatoid arthritis typically affects the MCP and PIP joints, sparing the DIP joints, and is strongly associated with HLA-DR4 . This autoimmune disease presents with morning stiffness and progressive joint deformities such as ulnar deviation.
  • ➤ Rheumatoid arthritis typically affects the MCP and PIP joints, sparing the DIP joints, and is strongly associated with HLA-DR4 .
  • ➤ Rheumatoid arthritis
  • ➤ MCP
  • ➤ PIP
  • ➤ HLA-DR4
  • ➤ This autoimmune disease presents with morning stiffness and progressive joint deformities such as ulnar deviation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with reddish urine. Laboratory results show a hemoglobin level of 7.8 g/dL, elevated serum LDH, and unconjugated bilirubin. A peripheral smear reveals pancytopenia. Flow cytometry is done and shown. Which of the following is unlikely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Positive Direct Coombs Test (DCT)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients presenting with hemolytic anemia and evidence of increased hemolysis (elevated LDH and unconjugated bilirubin), a positive Direct Coombs Test is unlikely if the primary pathology is aplastic anemia, emphasizing the importance of differentiating between hemolytic anemia and aplastic anemia in clinical practice.
  • ➤ In patients presenting with hemolytic anemia and evidence of increased hemolysis (elevated LDH and unconjugated bilirubin), a positive Direct Coombs Test is unlikely if the primary pathology is aplastic anemia, emphasizing the importance of differentiating between hemolytic anemia and aplastic anemia in clinical practice.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and hypoalbuminemia. Biopsy of his small intestine shows disrupted epithelial tight junctions. Which of the following proteins is most likely involved in maintaining the structure and function of the tight junctions in this patient’s epithelial cells?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Claudin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Claudins are critical proteins in tight junctions (zonula occludens) that help maintain epithelial barrier integrity by regulating paracellular transport. Disruption of claudins can lead to increased intestinal permeability, resulting in conditions like chronic diarrhea and malabsorption.
  • ➤ Claudins are critical proteins in tight junctions (zonula occludens) that help maintain epithelial barrier integrity by regulating paracellular transport.
  • ➤ Claudins
  • ➤ tight junctions (zonula occludens)
  • ➤ Disruption of claudins can lead to increased intestinal permeability, resulting in conditions like chronic diarrhea and malabsorption.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true regarding high-quality CPR for adults? Push hard (5-6cm depth) Push fast (100-120/min frequency) Allow for complete chest recoil Minimize interruptions in compressions ≤20 seconds Rotate compressor every 5 min. or earlier if fatigued
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ High-quality CPR for adults requires all the specified techniques to ensure optimal outcomes. Compressing at a depth of 5-6 cm and a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute, allowing for complete chest recoil, minimizing interruptions in compressions to under 10 seconds, and avoiding excessive ventilation are all recommended practices to maximize the effectiveness of cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
  • ➤ High-quality CPR for adults requires all the specified techniques to ensure optimal outcomes.
  • ➤ Compressing at a depth of 5-6 cm and a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute, allowing for complete chest recoil, minimizing interruptions in compressions to under 10 seconds, and avoiding excessive ventilation are all recommended practices to maximize the effectiveness of cardiopulmonary resuscitation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a 6-mm basal cell carcinoma on the tip of his nose. He is scheduled to undergo excision of the tumor in the operating room with repair of the defect using skin and subcutaneous tissue from his earlobe. Which of the following terms most appropriately describes this form of reconstructive surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Composite graft

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A composite tissue graft contains tissue in addition to the epidermis and dermis.
  • ➤ A composite tissue graft contains tissue in addition to the epidermis and dermis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 24 weeks gestation presents for a routine prenatal visit. She is pregnant with monochorionic twins. During the ultrasound, there is a concern for a complication specific to this type of twin pregnancy. Which of the following complications is specific to monochorionic twins?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) is a specific complication of monochorionic twin pregnancies , where abnormal vascular connections within the shared placenta result in unequal blood flow between the twins, leading to complications in both the donor and recipient twins.
  • ➤ Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)
  • ➤ monochorionic twin pregnancies

questions.text: A 57-year-old patient develops acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) after being admitted for severe pneumonia. He is being prepared for mechanical ventilation in the intensive care unit. Which of the following statements about lung-protective ventilatory settings is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: Tidal volume should be set at 4-6 ml/kg of ideal body weight (IBW).

options.label: B
options.text: Respiratory rate should be initially set at 12-16 breaths per minute.

options.label: C
options.text: Initial FiO2 should be set at 100% and reduced as tolerated to avoid oxygen toxicity.

options.label: D
options.text: PEEP should be set at 5 cm H2O and not adjusted.

questions.correct_answer: D. PEEP should be set at 5 cm H2O and not adjusted.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) PEEP should be set at 5 cm H2O and not adjusted

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When initiating mechanical ventilation, it is critical to start with safe settings tailored to the patient’s lung mechanics and underlying pathology. The initial PEEP setting should be low but requires careful adjustment, to balance lung recruitment and cardiac output.
  • ➤ When initiating mechanical ventilation, it is critical to start with safe settings tailored to the patient’s lung mechanics and underlying pathology.
  • ➤ The initial PEEP setting should be low but requires careful adjustment, to balance lung recruitment and cardiac output.

questions.text: The following laws have been enacted in India to protect the rights of women and children. Identify the pair that is incorrectly matched with its year of enactment:

options.label: A
options.text: The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act - 2012

options.label: B
options.text: The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition, and Redressal) Act - 2013

options.label: C
options.text: The Pre-conception and Pre-natal Diagnostic Techniques (Prohibition of Sex Selection) [PNDT] Act - 2002

options.label: D
options.text: The Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act - 2005

questions.correct_answer: C. The Pre-conception and Pre-natal Diagnostic Techniques (Prohibition of Sex Selection) [PNDT] Act - 2002
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The Pre-conception and Pre-natal Diagnostic Techniques (Prohibition of Sex Selection) [PNDT] Act - 2002

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The PNDT Act was enacted in 1994 to prevent sex-selective practices. The POCSO Act (2012) and Sexual Harassment Act (2013) address child protection and workplace safety, respectively. The Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act (2005) provides a legal framework for addressing domestic violence against women.
  • ➤ The PNDT Act was enacted in 1994 to prevent sex-selective practices.
  • ➤ The POCSO Act (2012) and Sexual Harassment Act (2013) address child protection and workplace safety, respectively.
  • ➤ The Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act (2005) provides a legal framework for addressing domestic violence against women.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to concerns about delayed eruption of his permanent teeth and abnormal appearance of his shoulders. Physical examination reveals a wide, flat skull, midface hypoplasia, and the ability to bring his shoulders together in front of his chest. X-rays of the chest are shown below. Which of the following skeletal abnormalities is most characteristic of this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Craniosynostosis with premature fusion of sutures

options.label: D
options.text: Multiple exostoses (bony outgrowths) on long bones

questions.correct_answer: A. Hypoplasia or absence of clavicles
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hypoplasia or absence of clavicles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cleidocranial dysostosis is characterized by hypoplasia or absence of clavicles , which allows for excessive shoulder mobility, delayed closure of the fontanelles , and dental abnormalities such as delayed tooth eruption. It is caused by mutations in the RUNX2 gene, which is essential for normal bone formation and osteoblast differentiation. Recognizing these skeletal features is critical for diagnosing the condition.
  • ➤ Cleidocranial dysostosis is characterized by hypoplasia or absence of clavicles , which allows for excessive shoulder mobility, delayed closure of the fontanelles , and dental abnormalities such as delayed tooth eruption.
  • ➤ Cleidocranial dysostosis
  • ➤ hypoplasia or absence of clavicles
  • ➤ delayed closure of the fontanelles
  • ➤ dental abnormalities
  • ➤ It is caused by mutations in the RUNX2 gene, which is essential for normal bone formation and osteoblast differentiation.
  • ➤ RUNX2
  • ➤ Recognizing these skeletal features is critical for diagnosing the condition.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the clinic with fatigue and night sweats. On physical examination, he has cervical lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. Laboratory studies reveal lymphocytosis with the peripheral blood smear image as shown. Flow cytometry confirms the presence of clonal CD5+ CD19+ B cells. A bone marrow biopsy shows infiltration with small, mature lymphocytes. He is diagnosed with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). Which of the following is most strongly associated with poor prognosis in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Deletion of 17p involving the TP53 gene

options.label: D
options.text: Hypermutation of the immunoglobulin heavy chain variable region (IGHV)

questions.correct_answer: B. Deletion of 17p involving the TP53 gene

Ans. B) Deletion of 17p involving the TP53 gene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Deletion of 17p , involving the TP53 gene , is strongly associated with a poor prognosis in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) . This mutation leads to a more aggressive disease and poorer treatment response.
